clues: This city is home to a famous clock tower that many mistakenly call Big Ben.
It has a river that runs through it and a bridge that has stood for centuries.
fun_fact: The London Underground is the oldest metro system in the world, opening in 1863.
More than 300 languages are spoken in London, making it one of the most diverse cities on the planet.
trivia: The Tower of London was once a royal palace, a prison, and even a zoo.
London’s black cabs require drivers to memorize over 25,000 streets in a test called 'The Knowledge'.

clues: Home to a famous wall that can be seen from space (not really, but it’s still impressive!).
This city hosted the Summer Olympics in 2008 and the Winter Olympics in 2022.
fun_fact: The Forbidden City has 9,999 rooms—one less than the mythical number of rooms in heaven.
Beijing’s Peking Duck is one of the most famous dishes in the world.
trivia: The Great Wall of China, just outside Beijing, stretches over 13,000 miles.
Beijing has seven UNESCO World Heritage Sites, the most of any city in the world.

clues: Known as the 'City of Joy' and famous for its Durga Puja festival.
It was once the capital of British India.
fun_fact: The Howrah Bridge in Kolkata is one of the busiest cantilever bridges in the world.
The Indian Museum in Kolkata is the oldest museum in India.
trivia: Kolkata is home to the famous Bengali sweets, Rosogolla and Mishti Doi.
It has one of the oldest tram networks in Asia, still operational today.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of Pearls' and famous for its biryani.
It has a historic fort that was once the seat of the Qutb Shahi dynasty.
fun_fact: The Charminar was built in 1591 and is an iconic landmark of the city.
Hyderabad’s HITEC City is a major IT hub in India.
trivia: The Koh-i-Noor diamond was once stored in Golconda Fort.
Hyderabad houses Ramoji Film City, the largest film studio complex in the world.

clues: This city is known for Marina Beach, one of the longest urban beaches in the world.
It was formerly called Madras.
fun_fact: Chennai is home to the second-largest film industry in India, Kollywood.
The Vandalur Zoo in Chennai is the first public zoo in India.
trivia: Chennai’s M.A. Chidambaram Stadium hosted the first-ever Ranji Trophy match.
The city has a railway station named after a Chief Minister, M.G. Ramachandran.

clues: This city is home to Bollywood, India's largest film industry.
It has a famous waterfront called Marine Drive, also known as the 'Queen's Necklace'.
fun_fact: Mumbai's Dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 lunchboxes daily with almost zero errors.
The Gateway of India was built to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary in 1911.
trivia: Mumbai was formerly called Bombay until 1995.
The Bandra-Worli Sea Link is made of steel wires equal to the Earth's circumference.

clues: This city has India’s largest mosque, Jama Masjid.
It is home to a 73-meter tall tower built in the 12th century.
fun_fact: Delhi has been inhabited since at least the 6th century BC.
The Lotus Temple in Delhi is open to all religions and has no clergy or sermons.
trivia: Delhi’s metro is the second oldest in India after Kolkata.
The Red Fort was the main residence of Mughal emperors for over 200 years.

clues: Known as the 'Silicon Valley of India'.
This city has a palace built by a famous king of Mysore.
fun_fact: Bangalore has the highest number of engineering colleges in India.
It is home to Lalbagh, a 240-acre botanical garden with a glasshouse inspired by London’s Crystal Palace.
trivia: The first-ever electric street light in Asia was installed in Bangalore in 1905.
Bangalore’s name is derived from 'Benda Kaluru', meaning 'boiled beans town'.

clues: This city is known as the 'Pink City' due to its colored buildings.
It has a palace with 953 windows built for royal women to observe the streets unnoticed.
fun_fact: Jaipur was India’s first planned city.
The Hawa Mahal was designed to resemble the crown of Lord Krishna.
trivia: Jaipur’s Jantar Mantar is home to the world’s largest stone sundial.
Amer Fort was built using red sandstone and white marble, blending Rajput and Mughal architecture.

clues: Known as the Silicon Valley of India due to its tech industry.
The city enjoys pleasant weather throughout the year.
fun_fact: Bengaluru has over 8000 startups, making it one of the top startup hubs in the world.
The city has the highest number of Pubs in India.
trivia: Bengaluru was the first city in India to get electricity in 1905.
It is home to India's aerospace research center, ISRO.

clues: This city is known for its canals, bicycles, and tulips.
It is home to a famous museum dedicated to a Dutch painter.
fun_fact: There are more bicycles than people in Amsterdam.
The city’s houses are often tilted due to the soft soil.
trivia: Amsterdam has over 1,200 bridges connecting its canals.
The Anne Frank House is one of the most visited places in the city.

clues: This city has one of the longest official names in the world.
It is famous for its floating markets and vibrant nightlife.
fun_fact: Bangkok’s real name has 169 letters in Thai.
It is home to the world's largest Chinatown.
trivia: The city experiences some of the worst traffic congestion in the world.
Bangkok is known as the ‘Venice of the East’ due to its canals.

clues: Home to a famous opera house with a sail-like design.
This city hosted the Summer Olympics in 2000.
fun_fact: Sydney Harbour Bridge is known as 'The Coathanger' due to its shape.
Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world.
trivia: Sydney's Taronga Zoo has over 4,000 animals from around the world.
The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build and opened in 1973.

clues: This city was once divided by a famous wall that fell in 1989.
It is known for its Brandenburg Gate and vibrant art scene.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice, with around 1,700 in total.
It is home to the largest train station in Europe.
trivia: Berlin’s public transport system covers more than 2,500 km of track.
The city has the largest Turkish population outside of Turkey.

clues: This city is home to one of the world’s most famous football clubs.
It has a royal palace with over 3,000 rooms.
fun_fact: Madrid is the highest capital city in Europe at 667 meters above sea level.
The city’s symbol is a bear reaching for a strawberry tree.
trivia: Madrid has the oldest restaurant in the world, founded in 1725.
The city was originally called Mayrit by the Moors.

clues: One of the world's oldest continuously inhabited cities.
It is famous for its ghats along the Ganges River.
fun_fact: Varanasi is believed to be over 3,000 years old.
The Banarasi sarees from this city are world-famous.
trivia: Varanasi is known as the spiritual capital of India.
It is home to the Kashi Vishwanath Temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva.

clues: This city has an ancient amphitheater known as the Colosseum.
It is home to an independent country within its borders.
fun_fact: The Vatican City, the world's smallest country, is located within Rome.
Rome’s Trevi Fountain collects about 3,000 euros in coins daily, which are donated to charity.
trivia: Ancient Romans used urine to clean their clothes because of its ammonia content.
Rome’s Pantheon has the largest unreinforced concrete dome in the world.

clues: This city is known for its K-pop culture and technological advancements.
It is home to the historic Gyeongbokgung Palace.
fun_fact: Seoul is one of the most connected cities in the world, with super-fast internet speeds.
The city is surrounded by mountains, offering great hiking opportunities.
trivia: Seoul’s subway system is one of the most advanced and extensive in the world.
The city was originally known as Hanyang during the Joseon Dynasty.

clues: Home to the tallest building in the world.
This city has an artificial island shaped like a palm tree.
fun_fact: Dubai’s police force uses luxury cars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris.
The Dubai Mall is one of the largest shopping malls in the world.
trivia: The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset twice—once from the ground and again from the top.
Dubai has no natural rivers, despite being a coastal city.

clues: Famous for its giant statue of Christ overlooking the city.
This city hosts one of the biggest Carnival festivals in the world.
fun_fact: The city’s name means ‘River of January’ in Portuguese.
Rio’s beaches, like Copacabana and Ipanema, are world-famous.
trivia: Sugarloaf Mountain is one of the city's most iconic landmarks.
The Maracanã stadium once held a record attendance of nearly 200,000 spectators.

clues: This city is famous for its beautiful cherry blossoms and traditional temples.
It was the imperial capital of Japan for over 1,000 years.
fun_fact: Kyoto has over 2,000 temples and shrines, making it a cultural hub of Japan.
It is home to the famous Fushimi Inari Shrine with thousands of torii gates.
trivia: Kyoto’s name means ‘Capital City’ in Japanese.
Many traditional Japanese arts, like tea ceremonies, originated here.

clues: Home to an ancient temple dedicated to the goddess Athena.
This city hosted the first modern Olympic Games in 1896.
fun_fact: Athens is one of the oldest cities in the world, with a recorded history of over 3,000 years.
The Parthenon has stood on the Acropolis for more than 2,400 years.
trivia: The Olympic flame is always lit in Olympia before traveling to the host city.
Athens is named after Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom and war.

clues: This city is home to the iconic Red Square and Kremlin.
It has the world's busiest metro system by daily ridership.
fun_fact: Moscow's metro stations are often called 'underground palaces' due to their beautiful architecture.
The city spans over 2,500 square kilometers, making it one of the largest cities in the world.
trivia: Moscow was founded in 1147, making it one of Russia’s oldest cities.
The city experiences some of the coldest winters among major global capitals.

clues: This city is known as the 'Venice of the North' due to its many canals.
It was the capital of Russia before Moscow.
fun_fact: Saint Petersburg has over 300 bridges connecting different parts of the city.
The famous Hermitage Museum contains over 3 million works of art.
trivia: The White Nights phenomenon occurs here, where the sun barely sets in summer.
It was founded by Tsar Peter the Great in 1703.

clues: This city is home to the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World.
The Nile River flows through this capital city.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years.
Cairo is known as 'The City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its many mosques.
trivia: The Sphinx of Giza has a missing nose, possibly removed by cannon fire or erosion.
Cairo’s Khan El-Khalili market is one of the oldest shopping districts in the world.

clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is known for its stunning Table Mountain.
It is home to Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.
fun_fact: Cape Town is one of the three capital cities of South Africa.
The city’s Kirstenbosch Botanical Gardens are among the best in the world.
trivia: Penguins can be found on Cape Town’s Boulders Beach.
Cape Town was originally a Dutch settlement in 1652.

clues: This city has a famous astronomical clock that dates back to the 15th century.
It is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires' due to its historic architecture.
fun_fact: Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle in the world.
Charles Bridge has stood for over 600 years and is one of the city's most famous landmarks.
trivia: The Czech Republic consumes the most beer per capita in the world.
Franz Kafka, the famous writer, was born in Prague.

clues: This city is famous for its tango dance.
The widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio, is located here.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires is often called 'The Paris of South America'.
The city has one of the highest bookstore-to-resident ratios in the world.
trivia: The Obelisk is one of the most recognizable landmarks of Buenos Aires.
Football is a huge passion here, with Boca Juniors and River Plate being fierce rivals.
